title: How to say correctly, 'the sky looks like dark grey' or 'The sky looks dark grey' - Quora

response.answer_text: The correct choice from those two options is "the sky looks dark grey", but that’s not what I would normally say: I would say "the sky is dark grey". Actually, I would only use dark grey if I wanted to be precise about the colour, for instance if I wanted to paint a picture where the sky was that exact colour. I would be more likely to say "the sky is very grey". The only time I would use "looks" in that way would be if I were going to make an inference from the colour. For instance, I might say "The sky looks very grey; I think it’s going to rain soon" or "Her eyes look very red; I think she has been crying."

To look like something means you are comparing it to something else and finding some similarity. So you would perhaps say: The sky looks like a dark grey blanket covering the distant hill. To merely observe the color of the sky as you are perceiving it, you could just say: The sky looks dark gray. Or: They sky looks dark and gray.
